Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: I was just settling in at home when my partner sighed, mentioning how their boss had been nitpicking all day. I could see the fatigue in their eyes, the way they lingered in the doorway, waiting for me to ask, to listen, to care. I wanted to be there, to offer a hug, to let them vent and feel heard. But my phone buzzed insistently—an urgent message from the plant manager. The main production unit was down again, sensor errors halting everything for half an hour now. They needed me to diagnose the problem, fast, before the delay spiraled into a costly shutdown. My mind raced with possible causes, but my heart tugged toward my partner, who needed comfort, not a distracted nod. I stood there, torn, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, knowing I couldn’t give it to both at once.
